docs.lead_paragraph: It is Thursday, prenatal day at the storefront health clinic on Nostrand Avenue, in the heart of Caribbean Brooklyn. So the narrow, brightly lighted waiting room is packed with round bellies and aching backs, baby strollers and mothers-to-be patiently listening to lectures on the virtues of milk and cheese. Thirty-three women have appointments this day. The federal and state governments pay for them to consult with a nutritionist, sign up for free milk and infant formula and be examined by a midwife -- this one in a brown straw bowler.

headline.main: Appeal Pending, Immigrant Mothers-to-Be Crowd Prenatal Clinic

docs.abstract: Article discusses illegal immigrants that receive prenatal care at health clinic in Brooklyn; according to recent court ruling, they are not entitled to such care financed with federal money, however New York continues to receive federal aid for program; legal conundrum arises because, although mothers are not eligible for benefits, their babies are citizens and entitled to Medicaid; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It is Thursday, prenatal day at the storefront health clinic on Nostrand Avenue, in the heart of Caribbean Brooklyn. So the narrow, brightly lighted waiting room is packed with round bellies and aching backs, baby strollers and mothers-to-be...

docs.lead_paragraph: Is research on stem cells derived from human embryos to liberals what the missile defense system is to conservatives? Well, not quite. There are many conservative supporters of such stem cell research, after all, just as there are some liberals opposed to it. Yet it is curious how many people highly skeptical about the current rush for a missile defense system are so enthusiastic about giving stem cell research a green light and a heavy dose of federal financing.

headline.main: Similar questions of faith underlie debates over stem cell research and missile defense shields.

docs.abstract: Peter Steinfels Beliefs column draws parallels between stem cell research and missile defense shield, issues looming large in national debate; for instance, proponents of both make sweeping arguments that their projects hold potential for warding off some of humanity's greatest perils; opponents say benefits are uncertain and lie in distant future; concludes issues are both conflicts of faith (M)
docs.snippet: Is research on stem cells derived from human embryos to liberals what the missile defense system is to conservatives? Well, not quite. There are many conservative supporters of such stem cell research, after all, just as there are some liberals...

docs.lead_paragraph: In these days of overworked air- conditioners, one should never discount the cooling power of brisk, breezy dialogue. Watching ''Music From a Sparkling Planet,'' Douglas Carter Beane's nimble escapist comedy about escapism, is like sinking into a frozen margarita -- or, to be more precise, one of those pastel-colored margaritas bearing the names of summer fruits. Like such drinks, Mr. Beane's new play, which opened last night at the Greenwich House Theater, is sweet, tasty and mildly inebriating, and it's finished before you know it. If at some point you find that it has turned to mush, that probably won't stop you from enjoying it until the last syrupy drop.

headline.main: For Some, It Isn't Easy to Come of Age Before 40

docs.abstract: Ben Brantley reviews Douglas Carter Beane's play Music From a Sparkling Planet, produced by Drama Dept; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study provides evidence that a pregnant woman can consume moderate amounts of caffeine without impairing her baby's growth and development. The new findings add to a body of conflicting research that explores the effects of caffeine on the developing fetus.

headline.main: Conflicting Views on Caffeine in Pregnancy

docs.abstract: New study provides evidence that pregnant woman can consume moderate amounts of caffeine without impairing her baby's growth and development; new findings add to a body of conflicting research that explores the effects of caffeine on developing fetus (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: By early next year, infant formulas sold in this country may have had an important change in their ingredients. The Food and Drug Administration has just approved the addition of two fatty acids that can enhance the neurological and visual development of children who are not breast-fed. These fatty acids, which are naturally present in breast milk, are already being added to formulas in 60 countries and have been endorsed as beneficial to infant development by the World Health Organization.

headline.main: An Enriching Change for Infant Formulas

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column welcomes FDA approval of two new ingredients for infant formulas, the fatty acids DHA and AA, saying they can enhance neurological and visual development of children who are not breast-fed; says products may be on market by early 2002; DHA and AA are manufactured by Martek Biosciences Corp (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The last taboo in movies, contrary to Catherine Breillat's statement in Kristin Hohenadel's article, is contraception, not sex.
docs.abstract: Sarah Grambs letter holds last taboo in movies is contraception, not sex (July 1 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The last taboo in movies, contrary to Catherine Breillat's statement in Kristin Hohenadel's article, is contraception, not sex.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is midafternoon on a Wednesday in early January, and Operating Room No. 5 at Vanderbilt University Medical Center is a backdrop of blue: blue scrubs on the 10 nurses and doctors who crowd around the O.R. table; blue sterile sheets on 28-year-old Kelly Hasten, who is about to undergo experimental surgery. The procedure will put her at risk for infections, hemorrhages and death. But Kelly will receive no physical benefits. Her body is simply the gatekeeper for the main event: an operation on a 24-week-old, one-pound fetus nestled inside her. To reach the fetus, Dr. Joseph Bruner slices a wide arc across Kelly's abdomen. Once the incision is complete, he pushes down on her stomach with his right hand while reaching inside with his left. Carefully, he nudges the uterus loose from its home. Then, with both hands, he gently lifts it out of Kelly's body, as if it were a fragile glass bowl, and rests it on top of her.
docs.abstract: Maggie Jones article on medical and ethical issues in fetal surgery, which is increasingly being attempted not simply to save lives but also to treat nonfatal illnesses; pioneering work of Drs Joseph Bruner and Noel Tulipan at Vanderbilt University Medical Center described; photos; pre-birth surgery also becomes enmeshed in abortion debate, as anti-abortion activists brandish photos taken during fetal surgery to bolster their position (M)
